|territory = 
* Spain cedes the Spanish Netherlands, Kingdom of Naples, Duchy of Milan and
  Sardinia to the Habsburg Monarchy, Sicily to the Duchy of Savoy and Gibraltar
  and Minorca to Britain.
* France is guaranteed all its former conquests but recognizes British
  sovereignty over Rupert's Land and Newfoundland and cedes Acadia and its half
  of Saint Kitts to Great Britain.
* The Dutch Republic retains various forts in the Southern Netherlands and
  annexes a part of Spanish Guelders.
* Spain cedes the Colony of SantÃ­ssimo Sacramento, in South America, to the
  Portuguese Empire
|
|result =
* Treaty of Utrecht (1713)
* Treaty of Rastatt (1714)
* Treaty of Baden (1714)
* Philip is recognized as King of Spain, but renounces any claim to the throne
  of France.
* Spain and Britain sign the [[Asiento]].
|

  this must be added, initially, Bavarian and Savoyard contingents

  own military strength now but a pale shadow of its former self â at the

|casualties1 = |casualties2 = |notes= }}


The 'War of the Spanish Succession' (1701â1714) was fought between two alliances
of European powers, including a divided Spain, over who had the right to succeed
Charles II as king of Spain. Rhea Marsh Smith, Spain: A Modern History
(University of Mischigan Press: Ann Arbor, Michigan, 1965) p. 231. It
ended with the Peace of Utrecht (1713), recognising King Philip V of
Spain. Rhea Marsh Smith, Spain: A Modern History, pp. 235-236. Philip
renounced his place in the French line of succession. Nonetheless, a union of
the French and Spanish crowns was, in effect, created. He retained the Spanish
overseas empire but gave up a number of European territories to other European
powers and granted the British the right to slave trading in Spain's American
colonies for thirty years.

Spanish power had suffered a steep decline under the reign of its last Habsburg
king, Charles II, so that by 1700 Spain's neglected forces were barely
considered those of a first rate power. Rhea Marsh Smith, Spain: A Modern
History, pp. 198 & 200-201. Rhea Marsh Smith, Spain: A Modern History
(University of Michigan Press: Ann Arbor, 1965) p. 205 However, Spain
still possessed by far the largest European empire with territories in southern
Italy and Milan, the southern Netherlands, the Philippines, vast territories in
the Americas and other smaller settlements and islands. For this reason, other
European powers feared that the possible unification of Spain with France would
drastically alter the European balance of power in favour of the French throne.
The war was fought primarily by forces supporting the French candidate: the
Spanish loyal to Philip V France and the Electorate of Bavaria, together known
as the Two Crowns, against those supporting the Austrian candidate, the Grand
Alliance: the Spanish loyal to Archduke Charles, the Holy Roman Empire, Great
Britain, the Dutch Republic, Portugal and the Duchy of Savoy. Rhea Marsh
Smith, Spain: A Modern History, pp. 203 & 230-244. Rhea Marsh Smith,
Spain: A Modern History, p.233 Rhea Marsh Smith, Spain: A Modern
History'', p. 233.

The war was fought mostly in Europe but included Queen Anne's War in North
America. It was marked by the military leadership of notable generals including
the Duc de Villars, the Jacobite Duke of Berwick, the Duke of Marlborough and
Prince Eugene of Savoy. Several battles are considered classics in history,
notably the Grand Alliance victories at Blenheim (1704) and Ramillies (1706),
which drove the French forces from Germany and the Netherlands, or the French
victory at Almansa (1707). Inconclusive fighting and skirmishing followed in
Spain with little result, and the action turned to France. After considerable
maneuvering and inconclusive action, the French were once again decisively
defeated by Marlborough and Eugene at the Battle of Oudenarde (1708). This
string of losses prompted Louis XIV to start negotiations, but the terms were
humiliating and he decided to press the war to its end.

This led to the Grand Alliance Pyrrhic victory at the Battle of Malplaquet
(1709) and a Two Crowns victory at the Battle of Villaviciosa (1710). Continued
skirmishing, sieges, and battles, such as the decisive victory of Denain (1712),
allowed the French to re-capture considerable ground, especially during 1712. At
the same time, a series of events led to the Allied cause faltering. The recall
of the Duke of Marlborough for political reasons, combined with a new parliament
pressing for peace, dramatically reduced the effectiveness of the British
forces. Peace negotiations between France and Britain started in secret. In
1711, Archduke Charles' elder brother Joseph died and the Archduke became
Emperor Charles VI. Other members of the Allies were thus presented with the
equally unsavoury possibility of a Spanish-German superpower in place of a Spanish-
French one.

The war, over a decade long, was concluded by the treaties of Utrecht (1713) and
Rastatt (1714). As a result, Philip V remained King of Spain but was removed
from the French line of succession, averting a union of the two kingdoms. The
Austrians gained most of the Spanish territories in Italy and the Netherlands.
France's hegemony over continental Europe was ended and the idea of a balance of
power became a part of the international order. Wolf, The Emergence of the
Great Powers: 1685â1715. p.92 Philip quickly revived Spanish ambition;
taking advantage of the power vacuum caused by Louis XIV's death in 1715, Philip
announced he would claim the French crown if the infant Louis XV died and
attempted to reclaim Spanish territory in Italy, precipitating the War of the
Quadruple Alliance in 1717.
